title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and provides a basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, to specify that specific information from a credible source must be received within 15 days for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. If there is insufficient evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law, the matter will be closed. The Attorney General must determine within 15 days if there is enough evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law to warrant a preliminary investigation. If insufficient evidence is found, the matter will be closed. If there is enough evidence, a preliminary investigation will commence. Additional information must come from a credible source. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel is amended to specify the scope of authority to investigate and prosecute alleged criminal violations requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel's authority is amended to fully investigate and prosecute alleged criminal violations, including perjury and obstruction of justice. The scope of authority is specified by the Attorney General. The independent counsel is granted authorities and duties to investigate and prosecute criminal violations, such as perjury and obstruction of justice, with the scope of authority specified by the Attorney General. The independent counsel is provided with office space within a Federal building by the Administrator of General Services, unless cost-effective alternatives are available. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies, including the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information. Previous amendments regarding limitations on expenditures are repealed. Amendments are made to section 594(f) of title 28, United States Code, to repeal prior amendments. A limitation on expenditures for the operation of any office of independent counsel is imposed, with funds only available for use after a 2-year period. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to allow for the termination of an independent counsel's office by the court under certain conditions. The independent counsel can be petitioned by the subject of an investigation more than 2 years after appointment, requesting the Department of Justice to complete the investigation or prosecution. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. The independent counsel must report monthly expenditures to specified committees. Periodic reappointment is required every 2 years after the original appointment. The court must decide on reappointment of the independent counsel every 2 years. If the counsel's office is not terminated, the court will reappoint the current counsel if deemed appropriate, or appoint a new qualified person if necessary. If the court fails to take action within 90 days, the counsel's office will terminate. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to Congress within 1 year of this Act's enactment, with recommendations to enhance cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, United States Code.
